questions.text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness. Menopause occurred 7 years ago. Colonoscopy 4 years ago disclosed no abnormalities. A serum lipid profile obtained last year was within the reference range. Two years ago, a Pap smear with testing for human papillomavirus showed no abnormalities. Mammography performed 10 months ago showed no abnormalities. She is a retired university professor and lives with her husband. She has no children. Her father developed colon cancer at the age of 75 years. She has no family history of hip fracture. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (128 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A fasting serum glucose level is 102 mg/dL. Screening for depression with a validated questionnaire is negative. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: No specific health maintenance recommendation is needed

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening mammography every 2 years in women aged 40–74 years with average risk for breast cancer. This patient had a normal mammogram 10 months ago, so she does not require further screening at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Screening for lipid disorders is recommended in all adults aged 20–75 years at least every 4–6 years. In adults aged 40–75 years, the screening interval can be shortened based on the individual ASCVD risk. Given that this patient had a normal serum lipid profile 1 year ago and has no significant risk factors for cardiovascular disease (e.g., history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, or smoking), her ASCVD risk is likely low. A repeat serum lipid profile is not warranted at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Individuals with a first-degree relative (FDR) with a history of colorectal cancer, like this patient, are generally recommended to obtain screening more frequently (every 5 years) and start earlier (40 years of age or 10 years before the youngest FDR's age at diagnosis). Because her last colonoscopy 4 years ago was normal and she lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), she does not require repeat screening at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening women ≥ 65 years of age for osteoporosis with bone measurement testing (e.g., dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry). For postmenopausal women < 65 years of age, the decision to screen should be based on an assessment of the patient's overall risk for osteoporosis. This patient has no significant risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., family history of hip fracture, smoking, alcohol consumption, low BMI), so screening is not indicated at this time.

E) CORRECT:

No specific health maintenance recommendation is needed at this time for this 61-year-old woman who is currently up to date with all recommended screening tests based on her age, history, and physical examination findings. The recommendations that this patient has followed include screening for cervical cancer (Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing every 5 years), colon cancer (every 5 years in patients with a first-degree relative with a history of colorectal cancer, every 10 years in the general population), and breast cancer (mammography every 1–2 years). Moreover, she does not have identifiable risk factors for cardiovascular disease (e.g., history of dyslipidemia, diabetes, hypertension, or smoking) or osteoporosis (e.g., family history of hip fracture, smoking, alcohol consumption, low BMI), which would warrant enhanced screening for these conditions.

See “Screening recommendations for nonpregnant women by age” table.

F) INCORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening women between 30 and 65 years of age for cervical cancer using any of the following strategies: every 3 years with cervical cytology, every 5 years with testing for high-risk human papillomavirus (hrHPV) testing, or every 5 years with hrHPV testing in combination with cytology. This patient had a normal Pap smear with testing for human papillomavirus 2 years ago, so she does not require further screening at this time.
questions.hint: This patient's history and physical examination findings do not suggest that she has a higher risk of morbidity than average.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. Two weeks ago, she gave birth to a healthy girl. Vaginal delivery was uncomplicated and mother and child were discharged after 3 days. Since the delivery of the child, the patient has had vaginal discharge that changed color from red to yellow. She has no pain with urination. She says that she has not been getting much sleep since her daughter's birth and often feels tired. She has not had depressed mood or excessive worrying. The child is exclusively breastfed. The patient has a history of well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. She used to take metformin that was switched to insulin during pregnancy. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. She lives with her husband, two children, and the newborn in a small town in Wyoming. Her only sexual partner is her husband. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilaterally engorged, slightly tender breasts with erythematous nipples and a firm, nontender uterine fundus palpable at the height of the symphysis. There are yellowish stains on the perineal pad. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Offer referral to a weight loss program
Screen for emotional and physical partner violence

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Referral to a weight loss program or other behavioral interventions is recommended by the US Preventive Services Task Force for patients with a BMI of 30 kg/m2 or higher to prevent obesity-related morbidity and mortality. This patient has a BMI of 27 kg/m2.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone levels are indicated to evaluate for thyroid disorders such as postpartum thyroiditis. Although postpartum thyroiditis can manifest with fatigue, other features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, palpitations, intolerance to heat) or hypothyroidism (e.g., cold intolerance, constipation) would be expected as well. Furthermore, postpartum thyroiditis is typically associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus, not type 2.

C) CORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening all women of reproductive age for intimate partner violence (IPV). According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), in the US, a little under 50% of women and men experience IPV during their lifetime. The risk of IPV increases during pregnancy and the postpartum period. Screening can help to address immediate threats and prevent long-term IPV-associated conditions (e.g., posttraumatic stress disorder). To screen for IPV, the physician can ask a single nonjudgmental and nonstigmatizing question (e.g., “Some of the patients I see have been hurt or threatened by someone close to them. Is this something that you have experienced?”). IPV screening tools include the HARK questions, HITS screening tool, and STaT questions. Management of IPV includes immediate and, most importantly, ongoing support.

The USPSTF does not recommend routine screening for IPV in other patient groups (men, women not of reproductive age, vulnerable individuals, older adults) because of a lack of evidence that such interventions provide any benefit to these patients. Other sources do recommend screening for IPV in these patient groups because of an absence of harm and a potential benefit. The WHO recommends targeted screening for patients with red flags for IPV.

D) INCORRECT:

Urine culture is indicated in the diagnostic workup of urinary tract infections (UTIs) in select cases (e.g., uncomplicated lower UTI if urinalysis is negative but suspicion persists, complicated lower UTI, suspected upper UTI). This patient has no signs of UTI (e.g., dysuria, fever) and her vaginal discharge is most consistent with normal lochia. In patients with suspected sexually transmitted infection (e.g., patients with thick yellow, malodorous vaginal discharge), other tests would be indicated (e.g., nucleic acid amplification test, vaginal smear).

E) INCORRECT:

Behavioral counseling on sexually transmitted infections (STIs) is recommended by the US Preventive Services Task Force for all sexually active adolescents and for adults at increased risk of STIs (e.g., who do not consistently use condoms and have several sexual partners). This patient is not part of either of these groups.
questions.hint: This patient is from Wyoming but the following step in management applies to all women of reproductive age in the US when they come to the office as a new patient.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination after starting a new job as a marketing manager. She feels well. Her medical history is remarkable for hypertension treated with ramipril, and prediabetes well-controlled with diet and exercise. She had asthma during childhood but has not required treatment since the age of 14 years. Last year, she had a kidney stone that passed spontaneously. Four years ago, she had a mammogram and a colonoscopy, which showed no abnormalities. She is sexually active with her husband only. She has no children. Menopause occurred at the age of 51 years. Her mother was diagnosed with renal cancer at the age of 69 years. She smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 12 years but quit 17 years ago. She drinks one to two glasses of wine nightly. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 78 kg (172 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 131/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. At this time, screening for which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Annual lung cancer screening with a low-dose CT scan is recommended for individuals aged 50–80 years who have a smoking history of ≥ 20 pack-year. Although this patient is 54 years old and a former smoker, she only has a 12-pack-year smoking history, which makes her unsuitable for lung cancer screening at this time.

B) CORRECT:

For women with an average risk of breast cancer, the USPSTF recommends mammography screening every 2 years starting no later than 40 years of age. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists and American Cancer Society also recommend starting screening mammography at 40 years of age and advise clinicians to consider screening annually rather than biennially. Because this patient is 54 years of age, and her last mammogram was 4 years ago, she is due for breast cancer screening.

See “Cancer screening” table.

C) INCORRECT:

According to the USPSTF, colorectal cancer screening with colonoscopy is recommended for all average-risk individuals aged 45–75 years every 10 years. Since this patient has no known risk factors for colorectal cancer (e.g., family history of colorectal cancer or hereditary cancer syndromes, personal history of adenomatous polyps, colorectal cancer, or inflammatory bowel disease) and her last colonoscopy performed 4 years ago showed no abnormalities, she does not require colorectal cancer screening at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) screening may be considered in patients who have a high risk of developing hereditary RCC (e.g., personal or family history of Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome). Although this patient's mother had RCC, the timing of her diagnosis suggests a sporadic, rather than hereditary, case of RCC, and puts this patient in an average, rather than a high-risk group for RCC. There is no routine RCC screening currently recommended for average-risk individuals.

E) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic cancer screening may be considered in patients who have a high risk of developing hereditary pancreatic cancer (e.g., personal or family history of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome). Although this patient has a number of predisposing factors for pancreatic cancer (e.g., smoking history, overweight, prediabetes, alcohol consumption), she has no personal or family history of any hereditary cancer syndromes and is therefore in an average, rather than a high-risk group for pancreatic cancer. There is no routine pancreatic cancer screening currently recommended for average-risk individuals.
questions.hint: The United States Preventive Services Taskforce (USPSTF) recommends screening for this type of cancer between 40 and 74 years of age.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman presents for a general preventive office visit. She has no known medical problems and takes no medications except for a multivitamin. Her last normal menstrual period was last week; she has had periodic gynecologic examinations elsewhere. She is married, has two children, and is sexually active with only her husband. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illegal drugs. She is an only child. Both her mother and father are alive and well. One of her cousins was diagnosed with colon cancer at age 63 and had a resection for early-stage disease.
The patient recently completed lipid screening at her workplace, revealing a total cholesterol level of 175 mg/dL (reference range, 125–200), HDL cholesterol of 32 mg/dL (≥46), and LDL cholesterol of 95 mg/dL (<130).
On physical examination, her blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, her heart rate is 76 beats per minute, her height is 168 cm, and her weight is 88 kg (BMI, 31.2). Her lung, heart, and abdominal examinations are normal.
Which one of the following screening tests or interventions should be recommended to this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient should be screened for type 2 diabetes, according to guidelines from both the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) and the American Diabetes Association (ADA).

The USPSTF recommends that adults aged 35 to 70 with a BMI ≥25 be screened for abnormal blood glucose levels as part of their cardiovascular risk assessment. The USPSTF considers any of the following screening tests acceptable: fasting plasma glucose measurement, glycated hemoglobin measurement, or the 2-hour oral glucose-tolerance test.

The ADA recommends screening for diabetes in all individuals older than age 35 — and also in individuals younger than age 35 who have a BMI ≥25 plus one additional diabetes risk factor (such as family history, hypertension, or dyslipidemia, including an HDL cholesterol level <35 mg/dL).

Key learning point: As part of their cardiovascular risk assessment, patients aged 35 to 70 with a BMI ≥25 should be screened for type 2 diabetes.

B) INCORRECT:

A specific screening test is recommended for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

For individuals at average risk for colorectal cancer, the USPSTF recommends fecal occult blood testing, sigmoidoscopy, or colonoscopy beginning at age 50 and continuing until age 75 (Grade A recommendation) and also suggests screening from age 45 to 49 as a Grade B recommendation. Although the USPSTF does not offer screening recommendations for individuals at increased risk for colorectal cancer, other guidelines suggest that patients should begin screening earlier if they have at least one first-degree relative who was diagnosed with colorectal cancer. These patients should start screening by age 40 at the latest. Given that this patient’s family member with colon cancer was not a first-degree relative, she does not fall into a high-risk category that requires earlier screening.

D) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF does not have a recommendation to screen for vitamin D deficiency because there is insufficient evidence of benefit. This patient is already taking a multivitamin and therefore is likely getting the recommended daily amount of vitamin D.

E) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF and the American Cancer Society (ACS) do not recommend breast self-examination to screen for breast cancer because there is no evidence that this practice is beneficial. For average-risk women, the USPSTF and ACS recommend screening mammography beginning at ages 50 and 45, respectively (although both organizations acknowledge that some women may wish to begin screening mammography as early as age 40).

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man presents for an annual wellness visit accompanied by his son and daughter. He has a history of coronary artery disease (three-vessel coronary artery bypass surgery 10 years ago), severe aortic stenosis, mild cognitive impairment, and type 2 diabetes with nephropathy (chronic kidney disease stage 4). He has been hospitalized three times in the past year for heart failure exacerbations.
He lives at home, where he generally stays on the first floor, using a four-wheeled walker for mobility. A private aide assists him with bathing and dressing. He requires assistance with instrumental activities of daily living.
During the visit, he and his son ask about routine screening for prostate cancer and colorectal cancer.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate regarding cancer screening in this patient?

choices.text: Recommend fecal immunochemical testing, and perform a digital rectal examination of the prostate
Recommend cessation of all cancer screening because of advanced age
Order a guaiac-based fecal occult blood test and a prostate-specific antigen test
Talk with him and his family about their understanding of his current health status and goals
Refer the patient for colonoscopy; do not screen for prostate cancer

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends colorectal cancer screening for all adults aged 45 to 75 years. Those aged 76 to 85 years should be screened only selectively, depending on their overall health status, preferences, and prior screening history. Several strategies are available for colorectal cancer screening, including fecal immunochemical testing (FIT) every year. FIT is noninvasive and can be done by patients at home to detect hidden blood in the stool. Colonoscopy has higher sensitivity but also carries a higher risk for complications, particularly in older patients; in addition, poor bowel preparation can hinder completion.

Although FIT and colonoscopy are acceptable options for colorectal cancer screening, neither one should be initiated in this patient without a shared decision-making conversation first. Given this patient’s multiple comorbidities and dependencies in activities of daily living, the risks of a colonoscopy likely outweigh the benefits. Although FIT is a lower-risk options, a positive result would lead to a colonoscopy; thus, it is important to discuss whether the patient would want to pursue colonoscopy and eventual treatment if their FIT was positive.

Because of inadequate sensitivity and specificity, a digital rectal examination should not be used for prostate cancer screening. Instead, when prostate cancer screening is performed, the main method used is prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing. However, an elevated PSA level can also be caused by benign prostatic hyperplasia or prostatitis, both of which are common conditions, particularly as patients get older. Elevated PSA levels have not been shown to be highly predictive of morbidity and mortality from prostate cancer. Given these limitations, the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends against screening for prostate cancer in men aged ≥70 years. For men aged 55 to 69 years, the decision to be screened for prostate cancer should be an individual one.

B) INCORRECT:

Typically, decisions should not be made based on age alone. As individual patients age, clinicians should reassess the risks and benefits of cancer screening with them to determine which tests, if any, may be appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends colorectal cancer screening for all adults aged 45 to 75 years. Those aged 76 to 85 years should be screened only selectively, depending on their overall health status, preferences, and prior screening history. Several strategies are available for colorectal cancer screening, including guaiac-based fecal occult blood testing (gFOBT) every year. gFOBT is noninvasive and can be done by patients at home to detect hidden blood in the stool. Colonoscopy has higher sensitivity but also carries a higher risk for complications, particularly in older patients; in addition, poor bowel preparation can hinder completion.

Although gFOBT and colonoscopy are acceptable options for colorectal cancer screening, neither one should be initiated in this patient without a shared decision-making conversation first. Given this patient’s multiple comorbidities and dependencies in activities of daily living, the risks of a colonoscopy likely outweigh the benefits. Although gFOBT is a lower-risk options, a positive result would lead to a colonoscopy; thus, it is important to discuss whether the patient would want to pursue colonoscopy and eventual treatment if their gFOBT was positive.

An elevated PSA level can also be caused by benign prostatic hyperplasia or prostatitis, both of which are common conditions, particularly as patients get older. Elevated PSA levels have not been shown to be highly predictive of morbidity and mortality from prostate cancer. Given these limitations, the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends against screening for prostate cancer in men aged ≥70 years. For men aged 55 to 69 years, the decision to be screened for prostate cancer should be an individual one.

D) CORRECT:

Cancer screening is associated with both risks and benefits. The benefits include the possibility of detecting precancerous growths or early localized cancer that can be treated to prevent subsequent morbidity and mortality. The risks include potential overtesting and overdiagnosis, which can lead to anxiety, unnecessary treatment, and potential complications, particularly with invasive diagnostic procedures. As individual patients age, clinicians should reassess the risks and benefits of cancer screening with them to determine which tests, if any, may be appropriate.

In this particular case, the patient and his son are asking about screening for prostate cancer and colorectal cancer. Prostate cancer screening is not recommended for men aged ≥70 years, and colorectal cancer screening should be considered only selectively in those aged ≥75 years. Typically, decisions should not be made based on age alone. Thus, the best next step is to initiate a shared decision-making conversation with the patient and his family, taking into consideration his comorbidities, functional status, life expectancy, and anticipated time to benefit, with a goal of developing an individualized care plan. Tools such as ePrognosis|Cancer Screening (https://eprognosis.ucsf.edu/) can assist in decision-making about cancer screening.

Key learning point: Before making a recommendation about routine cancer screening in an older adult, the clinician should consider the patient’s comorbidities, functional status, and life expectancy and then talk with the patient (and their family, if desired) about goals of care, in order to develop an individualized care plan.

E) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends colorectal cancer screening for all adults aged 45 to 75 years. Those aged 76 to 85 years should be screened only selectively, depending on their overall health status, preferences, and prior screening history. Several strategies are available for colorectal cancer screening, including fecal immunochemical testing (FIT) every year, guaiac-based fecal occult blood testing (gFOBT) every year, and colonoscopy every 10 years. FIT and gFOBT are noninvasive and can be done by patients at home to detect hidden blood in the stool. Colonoscopy has higher sensitivity but also carries a higher risk for complications, particularly in older patients; in addition, poor bowel preparation can hinder completion.

Although colonoscopy is an acceptable options for colorectal cancer screening, it should not be initiated in this patient without a shared decision-making conversation first. Given this patient’s multiple comorbidities and dependencies in activities of daily living, the risks of a colonoscopy likely outweigh the benefits.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents for a general preventive office visit. She has no known medical problems and takes no medications except for a multivitamin. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, her pulse is 76/min, her height is 168 cm, and her weight is 88 kg (BMI 31.2 kg/m2). questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The ADA recommends screening for diabetes in all individuals older than age 35 — and also in individuals younger than age 35 who have a BMI ≥25 plus one additional diabetes risk factor (such as family history, hypertension, or dyslipidemia, including an HDL cholesterol level <35 mg/dL).

Key learning point: As part of their cardiovascular risk assessment, patients aged 35 to 70 with a BMI ≥25 should be screened for type 2 diabetes.

A specific screening test is recommended for this patient.

For individuals at average risk for colorectal cancer, the USPSTF recommends fecal occult blood testing, sigmoidoscopy, or colonoscopy beginning at age 50 and continuing until age 75 (Grade A recommendation) and also suggests screening from age 45 to 49 as a Grade B recommendation. Although the USPSTF does not offer screening recommendations for individuals at increased risk for colorectal cancer, other guidelines suggest that patients should begin screening earlier if they have at least one first-degree relative who was diagnosed with colorectal cancer. These patients should start screening by age 40 at the latest.

D) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF does not have a recommendation to screen for vitamin D deficiency because there is insufficient evidence of benefit. This patient is already taking a multivitamin and therefore is likely getting the recommended daily amount of vitamin D.

E) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF and the American Cancer Society (ACS) do not recommend breast self-examination to screen for breast cancer because there is no evidence that this practice is beneficial. questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. Two weeks ago, she gave birth to a healthy girl via uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Since the delivery of the child, the patient has had vaginal discharge that changed color from red to yellow. She has no pain with urination. She says that she has not been getting much sleep since her daughter's birth and often feels tired but has not had depressed mood or excessive worrying. Is this something that you have experienced?”). IPV screening tools include the HARK questions, HITS screening tool, and STaT questions. questions.hint: The following step in management applies to all women of reproductive age in the US when they come to the office as a new patient.

questions.text: During a routine check-up, a 50-year-old woman with a strong family history of breast cancer requests screening to detect any early malignant changes. Which test property is most important to minimize missed diagnoses in this setting?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High specificity reduces false positives by correctly identifying individuals without the disease. However, in screening, especially for high-risk conditions like breast cancer, the priority is to minimize missed diagnoses. High sensitivity is more important to ensure early detection, even if it results in some false positives that require further testing.

B) CORRECT:

High sensitivity is essential for screening tests to minimize false negatives, ensuring early detection of nearly all individuals with the disease. In breast cancer screening, especially for those with a strong family history, high sensitivity is crucial to identify abnormal findings at initial stages. This reduces the risk of missed diagnoses, allowing for timely follow-up with more specific diagnostic tests, which is vital for improving outcomes in high-risk populations.

Key learning point: High sensitivity is the most important characteristic for a cancer screening test to ensure early detection and minimize false negatives.

C) INCORRECT:

High positive predictive value (PPV) indicates that a positive result is likely a true positive, but it does not ensure detection of all disease cases. PPV is influenced by disease prevalence and is more relevant for confirming diagnoses. In screening, high sensitivity is prioritized to capture most disease cases, even at the cost of some false positives.

D) INCORRECT:

High overall accuracy reflects a test's ability to identify both diseased and non-diseased individuals. However, it does not specifically address minimizing missed diagnoses. In screening, especially for conditions like breast cancer, the focus should be on high sensitivity to detect early malignant changes, rather than overall accuracy, which may obscure deficiencies in detecting true disease cases.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to your clinic for an annual health maintenance examination. She reports feeling well and has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She is currently sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. Her immunizations are up to date. Vital signs are normal. Physical and pelvic examinations are normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Screening for herpes simplex virus infections is not recommended unless the individual has a history of anogenital lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

A complete blood count would be required if the patient had any signs of an infection, inflammation, or anemia but is not routinely necessary in a young individual with no symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Routine screening for type 1 diabetes mellitus is not recommended. Screening for type 2 diabetes (e.g., with HbA1c) is not recommended until age 40 years unless certain risk factors (e.g., obesity, hypertension, family history) are present.

D) CORRECT:

Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) is highly sensitive and specific for C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae and is the gold standard for screening for these infections. Genital chlamydia and gonorrhea may be asymptomatic but can cause complications if left untreated (e.g., infertility, pelvic inflammatory disease). Since this patient is sexually active, it is recommended that she be screened for C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae, even though she is asymptomatic.

For individuals at higher risk (e.g., men who have sex with men, individuals with HIV, current or former inmates, individuals with a substance use disorder, individuals from certain Indigenous communities), opt‑out screening for chlamydia and gonorrhea every 3 months is recommended. Providers should follow the relevant provincial or local guidelines for these specific groups. All pregnant individuals should be tested at their first prenatal visit in the first trimester and rescreened during the third trimester.

Key learning point: Sexually active young individuals should have annual nucleic acid amplification testing for chlamydia and gonorrhea, with more frequent screening for those at high risk.

E) INCORRECT:

The CTFPHC recommends cervical cancer screening with a Pap smear every 3 years starting at age 25 for women who are or have been sexually active. Cervical cancer is extremely rare in women < 20 years of age. In Canada, vaccination against HPV is included in the routine immunization schedule and is delivered through publicly funded school-based programs. It should ideally be administered before any sexual contact to be most effective. Individuals aged 9–20 years receive 1 dose of the 9-valent vaccine, whereas individuals aged 21–26 years receive two doses.
questions.hint: Annual chlamydia and gonorrhea screening is recommended by the 2025 PHAC guidelines for sexually active individuals < 25 years of age (and under age 30 per the 2021 CTFPHC guidelines)

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to your clinic for a general preventive visit. She has no known medical conditions and takes only a multivitamin. Her last visit to a physician was 6 years ago. On examination, her blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, height is 168 cm, and weight is 88 kg (BMI 31). Lung, heart, and abdominal examinations are normal. Which one of the following screening tests or interventions should you recommend for this patient?

choices.text: No additional screening is required at this time.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The CTFPHC does not recommend advising women to routinely practice breast self-examination to screen for breast cancer because there is no evidence that this practice reduces mortality, and it may lead to unnecessary biopsies. For average-risk women, the CTFPHC recommends screening mammography every 2–3 years for those aged 50–74; routine screening is not advised for women aged 40–49, although those who wish to be screened after an informed discussion may be offered mammography on an individual basis.

B) INCORRECT:

A specific screening test is recommended for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Routine screening for vitamin D deficiency is not recommended because there is insufficient evidence of benefit. This patient is already taking a multivitamin and, therefore, is likely getting the recommended daily amount of vitamin D.

D) INCORRECT:

The CTFPHC recommends colorectal cancer screening among patients aged 50–74 years with fecal occult blood testing every 2 years or flexible sigmoidoscopy every 10 years, but advises against routine screening before age 50 or after age 74.

E) CORRECT:

According to Canadian guidelines, adults should have their 10-year risk of type 2 diabetes (T2DM) estimated with a validated risk calculator such as the Finnish Diabetes Risk Score (FINDRISC) or Canadian Diabetes Risk Questionnaire (CANRISK). The CTFPHC advises that asymptomatic adults ≥ 18 years of age with one or more risk factors (e.g., obesity, hypertension) undergo this risk assessment every 3–5 years. Diabetes Canada recommends the risk assessment for all adults aged 40–74 years and for younger adults with additional risk factors. These risk calculators can categorize patients as low risk, moderate risk, high risk, and very high risk based on their 10-year probability of T2DM.

The CTFPHC recommends a blood test for T2DM every 3–5 years in high-risk individuals and annually in those at very high risk. Diabetes Canada advises blood test screening every 3 years for individuals at high risk and those ≥ 40 years of age. Earlier or more frequent testing is recommended for individuals at very high risk or strong risk factors such as overweight, family history, hypertension, or dyslipidemia (including HDL < 1.0 mmol/L). The preferred screening test is glycated hemoglobin (A1C), but fasting plasma glucose or the 2-hour oral glucose-tolerance test are acceptable alternatives.

Key learning point: Individuals aged 40–74 years and those with risk factors for type 2 diabetes mellitus should have their 10-year risk assessed using a validated tool (e.g., FINDRISC, CANRISK).

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no personal or family history of serious illness, and underwent a mammography one year ago. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years in her twenties. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Physical examination is normal. Serum lipid studies and glucose concentration are within reference ranges. Which one of the following screening studies is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The CTFPHC recommends a screening mammography every 2–3 years for average-risk women aged 50–74, but current guidelines recommend against offering BRCA1/2 testing routinely to average-risk women. The SOGC recommends genetic counselling and potential BRCA1/2 testing for women who meet established familial or clinical high-risk criteria (e.g., early-onset breast, ovarian, or male breast cancer); this patient has no such family history.

B) INCORRECT:

Routine thyroid‐stimulating hormone screening in asymptomatic nonpregnant adults is not recommended. Pregnancy (particularly during the first trimester) can interfere with normal circulating levels of TSH. Women who are planning pregnancy and are at increased risk for thyroid disorders (e.g., family history of autoimmune thyroid disease, presence of a goiter) can be screened, but universal screening is not generally recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

The CTFPHC advises beginning with a FRAX assessment in women ≥ 65 years of age and proceeding to DEXA only if pharmacotherapy is being considered. The 2023 Osteoporosis Canada guideline recommends DEXA screening for all women ≥ 70 years; for those 65–69 years of age with ≥ 1 significant risk factor (e.g., personal or parental hip fracture, chronic glucocorticoid use, significant alcohol consumption, current smoking); and for women aged 50–64 who have sustained a fragility fracture or have ≥ 2 significant risk factors. Since this 53-year-old patient has no significant risk factors, osteoporosis screening is not indicated at this time.

D) CORRECT:

The 2010 Canadian Association of Gastroenterology (CAG) and 2016 Canadian Task Force on Preventive Health Care (CTFPHC) guidelines both recommend screening average-risk asymptomatic adults aged 50–75 years for colorectal cancer, as early detection in this group significantly lowers mortality. Recommended methods are biennial fecal tests (e.g., immunochemical or high-sensitivity guaiac occult blood tests) or flexible sigmoidoscopy every 10 years. Because of long wait times, greater resource demands, and higher risks without clear evidence of superior efficacy, colonoscopy is not recommended for routine screening of average-risk adults, but its use is recommended for follow-up on any positive screening test result. Neither guideline supports routine screening before age 50, though rising early-onset colorectal cancer rates in Canadians under 50 have prompted some experts to suggest beginning at 45. After age 75, the CTFPHC advises against routine screening; the CAG, however, suggests individualized decisions for those aged 76–85.

Individuals with a first-degree relative with colorectal cancer or advanced adenoma diagnosed at < 60 years of age should start screening with colonoscopy at age 40 or 10 years earlier than the index patient's age at diagnosis, whichever is earlier.

Key learning point: Colorectal cancer screening with fecal tests or sigmoidoscopy is recommended for average-risk adults starting at age 50 and continuing until age 75.

E) INCORRECT:

Routine ECG screening in asymptomatic low-risk adults does not decrease myocardial infarction or stroke risk. Likewise, evidence is insufficient to support ECG screening for atrial fibrillation (Afib), although the 2020 Canadian Cardiovascular Society (CCS) and Canadian Heart Rhythm Society (CHRS) guidelines recommend screening for Afib with pulse or single-lead ECG rhythm checks during routine visits for individuals aged ≥ 65 years.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine check-up before starting a new job. She has no current concerns. Her last routine check-up was 3 years ago, and she has not seen a doctor since. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She exercises regularly and has a balanced diet. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. Her father was diagnosed with hypertension at age 52. Her maternal grandmother was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 72. She has never smoked tobacco or used illicit drugs. She drinks alcohol socially. She is 167 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 64 kg (141 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While hypertension screening is recommended for all adults starting at 18 years of age, this is typically done with office-based blood pressure measurements rather than ambulatory monitoring, which is reserved for suspected white coat hypertension or masked hypertension. This 23-year-old patient with normal blood pressure (116/74 mm Hg) and no risk factors should have routine hypertension screening every 3–5 years using standard office measurements.

B) INCORRECT:

Screening for diabetes using fasting plasma glucose is recommended for adults aged 35–70 years with overweight or obesity, or for younger individuals with additional risk factors (e.g., a family history of diabetes, hypertension, or signs of insulin resistance). As this patient is 23 years of age, has a normal BMI, and no identifiable risk factors, fasting glucose screening is not currently indicated.

C) CORRECT:

Pap smear and/or HPV testing detect precancerous and cancerous cervical changes, allowing early intervention to prevent progression to cervical cancer. Both the American Cancer Society (ACS) and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommend screening, although their starting ages and intervals differ slightly. The USPSTF advises beginning at age 21 with Pap smear alone every 3 years until age 29, and for individuals aged 30–65 years, either primary HPV testing every 5 years, HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years, or Pap smear alone every 3 years. In contrast, recent guidelines from the ACS, the American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology, and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommend starting primary HPV testing every 5 years at age 25, with HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years as an alternative, and Pap smear alone every 3 years if HPV testing is unavailable. As this patient is 23 years of age, asymptomatic, and up-to-date with other preventive screenings, she should undergo cervical cancer screening with a Pap smear.

D) INCORRECT:

Lipid panel testing is recommended for adults starting at 20 years of age for cardiovascular risk assessment. For individuals with a low risk and a normal lipid profile, repeat screening is generally advised every 4 to 6 years. As this patient had a routine check-up 3 years ago, is healthy, has a normal BMI, and has no cardiovascular risk factors, lipid testing is not currently indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Mammography is recommended for breast cancer screening starting at age 40–50 years, depending on guidelines, and is not indicated for asymptomatic women under 40 years of age without high-risk conditions for breast cancer (e.g., BRCA mutation). For women with a family history of breast cancer, it is generally recommended to start breast cancer screening 10 years before the age of the earliest diagnosis in the family, but not before the age of 30 years.

Individuals with a genetic predisposition to breast cancer (e.g., BRCA mutation) should begin screening between the ages of 25 and 29 years. For individuals aged ≤ 29 years, breast examination every 6–12 months and annual breast MRI are recommended.
questions.hint: Screening recommendations for women differ by age and risk factors.
